RE8 is the last stop in the chronological story in Resident Evil saga so far and caps off my month of re-playing the modern RE games.  This was my second playthrough and I found this to be an incredibly strong RE game but a weak sequel to RE7 that actually, in my opinion, undermines a lot of the gut punch in the Louisiana narrative.  RE8 has a stellar stage set in yet another undisclosed village in Europe.  The comparisons to RE4 are inevitable and RE8 is overall a fantastic package that addresses almost every complaint I have with RE7.

(+)  RE8 is arguably the best designed game in the series.  I found the entire game lovingly constructed with some areas being the most well-realised and executed you can find in the horror genre.  The castle of Lady Dimitrescu with its rotten dungeons and the waterfall Beneviento manor with it's accompanying graveyard are the stand-outs for me.  I was swallowed in the exploration side of RE8 and engrossed in the gameplay as it only gently guides you through giving you the agency of being stuck with Ethan and having to map out your plan and adapt when it all inevitably goes wrong.  The fidelity of display is a real punch up from RE7 and the character design is stunning, Mia has thankfully lost her spaghetti hair!  The creatures that overwhelmed the village and that spill out of the dungeons are incredible and the variety of enemy design has seen the most love and care.  The gameplay is a lot more responsive and even though we've tipped into action there's still a lot of surprises, twists and turns waiting for you.  Creatures can literally rise from their graves, fall out of trees and smash through walls and it always kept my eyes on the spectacular world design which was a nice way of keeping you in Ethan's shoes.  There's a lot lifted from RE4 but I personally think this is what RE should be shooting for when going for an action game so I loved how exploration led to upgrading weapons, how killing enemies fuelled the gameplay loop and how you've always got control in the action, you're rarely in cutscenes for anything other than story.  The gameplay is a lot more energetic and I was never sure headshots were the way to go, the Lycan's literally gyrate like they're in the Thriller music video and they pushed pressure onto me which always kept me on the backfoot.  The sound design has also seen some bulking and it's some of the best in the series.  Wind can whip around buildings and through the castle, snow is constantly crunching underfoot and footsteps echo off stone floors.

(-)  I don't have much to gripe about other than the game pulling the emotional rug out from under RE7 and, at least in my opinion, completely muddying the fresh take on RE by sloppily tipping the old lore into the story and undoing a lot of the delicate emotional crafting done in RE7.  The twist with Ethan left me salty when I first played the game four years ago and I haven't replayed RE8 until now.  I still hate the twist and think it really takes away from the Winter's story as well as partially ruining my favourite moment in the entire series with Ethan emotionally connecting with Jack in RE7.  I've mellowed out on it now but I really think they should have hesitated in tying this to the old games, especially as RE7 was the breath of fresh air that saved the series.  The game also cheekily locks areas off behind you and is obviously baiting a new game plus playthrough which was infuriating to my beaver-ish OCD as I like to collect everything in each area before moving on and I didn't finish upgrading anything despite ticking all but a few areas off being fully searched.

Overall, I was with the game through giant Vampires, through werewolves, through giant fish and through talking dolls but it lost me right at the narrative's crescendo.  The gameplay is engaging and the atmosphere is electrifying so I would absolutely recommend this game.  I was finished in 11 hours but that was me completing the game as thoroughly as I could with a lot of backtracking.  I had zero technical problems with it and is yet another example of the fantastic RE Engine.  It worked perfectly with my X1X controller I would recommend this game to all horror fans.

I feel Capcom went all in with this one. They saw what worked in previous installments and added them. Although similar to RE7, RE8 does much more and instead of being great at any one particular area, it tries to be good at mutiple aspects. It has been one of the most enjoyable titles I have played in a while. 

The game is mostly action-packed but has its own creepy and terrifying moments. Its not as scary as RE7, also the villains could have been a bit more developed. But it definitely expands the lore and makes the events of the previous game much more disturbing. Just 2 guys going through insurmountable odds, so you move from being helpless, emotional, scared and downright badass when needed.

This game is shorter and easier to 100% compared to RE7. Mercenaries was fun, but could have been better. Shadows of Rose DLC was a nice way to introduce a new character with new gameplay mechanics.

A must play if you played RE7 or other RE games, but its better not to make this your first game into the franchise.

Resident Evil Village is a first-person survival horror game that continues the story of Ethan Winters. The plot centers on the search for his kidnapped daughter in a remote European village. The narrative mixes gothic themes with modern bioweapon lore, creating a structured progression through distinct regions.

Exploration balances linear paths with optional rooms. Players collect keys, solve simple puzzles, and unlock shortcuts. Resource scarcity shapes decision-making. Ammunition and healing items are limited, pushing cautious aim and route planning.

Combat emphasizes weapon upgrades and enemy crowd control. Ethan can block attacks to reduce damage. Enemy types vary in speed and pressure. Boss encounters are scripted set pieces with clear weak points. Progression through the merchant system improves firepower and inventory.

Atmosphere relies on lighting, sound design, and environmental detail. The village hub changes over time as threats increase. Audio cues warn of danger. Level themes range from classic horror to action-focused segments, maintaining pacing variety.

Character upgrades use currency gained from exploration and combat. Inventory management returns as grid-based organization. Crafting supplements supplies but cannot replace poor aim. Weapon attachments alter recoil, reload, and spread.

Story delivery uses cutscenes and collectible files. Dialogue remains concise. Familiar franchise characters appear briefly. Plot twists escalate toward a high-intensity finale. Emotional tone is present, but delivery remains functional for pacing.

Resident Evil Village targets players who want hybrid horror and action. It may feel less tense than earlier entries but offers strong atmosphere and progression. Replay value comes from higher difficulties, new game+ upgrades, and extra challenges.

A first person survival horror game that puts you in Ethan Winters' shoes once again, now more battle hardened than before and better equipped to take down all the evil residents. This time around you have a more open map (or maybe just larger than usual) set in a rural European village with much to admire in terms of scenery, and as these things go you get to explore an absolutely gorgeous gothic castle as well. The design of it all is just superb and the level of graphical fidelity also plays a big part in bringing it out and the atmosphere is often excellent as well.

In terms of gameplay, you have exploration, inventory puzzles and combat. The puzzles are as you would expect and engaging if that is your sort of thing. The combat is a usually tense affair that will need you to both act quickly and aim carefully to take down enemies without letting your limited resources run dry. The sound design and the way enemies react to being shot in different body parts does a lot to make the gunplay feel satisfying. You also have an upgrade system for weapons based on getting money from enemies or optional puzzles, sort of like Resident Evil 4. This game's flavour of zombies make for intimidating adversaries, and when it comes to some of the major antagonists they are stylish, terrifying and highly entertaining villians. As far as the story goes it is pretty standard for the series but still engaging and a good reason to partake in all the sci-fi survival horror shenanigans the series is known for.

Overall I can strongly recommend it to fans of first person shooters and survival horror games.

This is a careful recommendation, and the main reason is... I can't choose what sort of person to recommend this to. There's such a variety of you, I can't quite pick one.

As an RE game, it has some of the mechanical hallmarks that you're likely familiar with. Smart ammo preservation, finding key items to progress, combining treasures. It's all there, but the campiness... I can't tell whether it's campy in a new but similar flavor, or not at all.

Ethan's such a weird protagonist, being the wimpiest or at least physically weakest protagonist the series has seen, while overcoming some of the worst odds any RE protag has been in. I'd almost call him John McCoolGuyAmerican as a joke, but I have a hard time being really reductive about him. The most precise thing I can say though, is that Ethan's never having a good time, not even when he's just at home being a Daddy. Dude's gonna join Guts in the Can't-Catch-A-Fuckin'-Break club.

As an FPS, I feel like I am fighting the controls most of the time. I wouldn't say that's a failing on the design, as it seems intentional, meant to ramp up the tension. Ethan's just a civilian using guns well past his competency (even though he's had military training between 7 and 8? or did I just imagine that?), so he's got that awkward ol' weapon sway and imprecision past the first shot. It's annoying, it throws me off and I don't like it, but having tight shooting controls would undermine the atmosphere the game's working so hard to set up. I'm not conflicted on the matter, it should be this way, even if I don't like it.

It was rather recent (let's say Months) since I finished RE7. As a new experience, I respect its chops but felt some fun was lacking. Turning RE into a straight-played horror was an interesting choice, just too bad I don't care at all for swamp environments in videogames. Personal aesthetic preference notwithstanding, RE8 across the board felt like an improvement on it. RE feels at its best when it throws the surreal at your normal mug, and forces you to deal with it spectacularly. Or as the old adage says: "When in doubt, C4". RE8 feels like it's all about that. It's not your 'human gumption' that overcomes these supernatural threats, it's that your contemporary means (ramped up to 11) were enough to deal with the situation. Except for that poison dagger, that just felt a little too convenient if you ask me.

So I guess I need to review this based on the conclusion of its merit as an RE game, and as a horror fps shooter.

As a horror shooter, it doesn't keep as organically tense as 7, I feel. Duke's Emporium game-ifies your resource management enough that any time I felt worried was back at the start, when I had little to trade, and the second major section where it was all scares and no combat. After that, tougher enemies are less frightening as more annoying, or a 'problem' for you to either navigate around or deal with directly. They become combat challenges instead, which makes Ethan's poor gun handling stand out more as a sore point then.

As an RE game? Yeah, RE7 didn't feel like much of an RE game mechanically, and RE8 completely addressed that through all of its improvements. Upgrading guns, unlocking unlimited ammo, simple crafting. Really, it felt as though RE4 had been given the horror treatment and toned down the campiness. Is it bad? Better? It's different, that's what it is.

Is this a good game you should play? That's going to depend what you want out of it, and hopefully the above review helps a little with that.

This Resident Evil game is a direct sequel to RE7, so even though you get a little refresher at the beginning, it’s best to have played the previous game for a more immersive experience.

Ethan, Mia, and their newborn baby are now living in Romania, and as a Romanian, I loved the little nods to our culture scattered throughout the game; from the design of the houses and the names of foods to the famous Castle Dimitrescu, which seems like a mix of several iconic Romanian castles.

The action kicks off when Mia is shot, and Chris Redfield and his team show up to take Rose and Ethan away. On the way, the vehicle transporting them crashes, killing everyone except Ethan. Now it’s his duty to find Rose, save her, and get the hell out.

The game is filled with mystical creatures, from lycans to vampires, ghouls, and all kinds of horrifying mutations. The roster of villains is amazing. Lady Dimitrescu will send shivers down your spine, and after you manage to deal with her, the rest of the family feels like a breeze. It might be because you spend so much time in her castle, and the developers likely shortened the others’ stories in her favour, which I honestly don’t mind. The second scariest villain, after her, is the puppet. Puppets are already creepy, but that chapter of the game will give you nightmares.

The art is stunning, from the intricate details in the houses to the fluid character animations and breathtaking landscapes, it all feels like a true labour of love. The soundtrack and voice acting are equally spectacular.

If I compare my experience with RE7, I enjoyed Village more. It felt more forgiving than the previous game, and as someone more invested in story than survival horror mechanics, it was satisfying knowing I had a higher chance of making it through.

Is Resident Evil Village a perfect game? I don’t know. But it’s definitely up there among the best I’ve ever played. Give it a go, it’s an awesome experience.

Exploration is immersive and satisfying. Hidden rooms, collectibles, and environmental storytelling encourage curiosity, while puzzles and traps create moments of tension and reward careful observation. Upgrading weapons and discovering new tools gives a tangible sense of progression and empowerment.

The story is gripping, dark, and cinematic. Resident Evil Village delivers memorable characters, shocking twists, and a narrative that keeps players invested from start to finish, blending horror and action seamlessly.

[b]Resident Evil Village[/b] is the eighth main entry in the franchise and once again delivers top-tier survival horror in first person.
The story picks up right after RE7, so it’s highly recommended to play that one first. This time, Ethan finds himself stranded in a remote Eastern European village while trying to save his daughter.

The gameplay closely follows the foundations of RE7: you manage a small inventory, craft supplies, solve light puzzles and fight your way through a world filled with monstrous creatures and wonderfully unhinged boss encounters. Overall, RE8 is less terrifying than RE7, but it still offers several truly unsettling moments.

The story is fantastic in my opinion. Sure, there are a few cheesy lines in classic RE fashion, but the emotional payoff they were aiming for works surprisingly well. The ending also delivers a couple of intriguing hints at what future titles might explore.

The DLC [b]Shadows of Rose[/b] stood out to me the most and even made me tear up, something I never expected from a Resident Evil game. It tries out a few new gameplay ideas that are both bold and satisfying.

The horror isn't the focus this time around, but is implemented well, even if it is overall less scary than most RE games. And as far as RE games go, the story is good, the characters are interesting and entertaining, the unlockables are fun, the story dlc is solid, and the Mercenaries mode is action packed as ever. Being a sequel to RE7 that takes heavy inspiration from RE4 and European folklore, it doesn't do justice to any prior material, but does at least have better weapon and enemy variety than RE7, and it never ceases bore the player. If you're interested in RE Village or the Ethan duology, this game is definitely worth buying bundled with RE7 (on at least a 75% sale). Also, hot vampires (extra enjoyable for masochists).

[i]What do you expect from a survival-horror shooter game? [/i] Village manages to do everything in a certain style and quality. Great thrilling moments, lots of action with a wide variety of monsters and many different locations to explore in just 7-8 hours of playtime. But most importantly, this game connects the dots of the series' story and makes a fine conclusion to Biohazard.

[h3] Best One in the Franchise [/h3] 
Village may not be the one with strongest atmosphere, but it certainly has the best action mechanics and the scariest, PT style horror section. While Biohazard achieves the right dose of thriller, can't maintain it for the rest of the game. But pacing is never the problem with Village. It makes you feel like prey, then hunter, then prey, then hunter... Until a certain point in game where the story began to reveal and it's all you care.

[h3] Apart from RE, what makes RE: Village one of the best in Survival-horror genre?[/h3] 
This game never bore me, and I think it's very hard for someone who's into this genre to get bored. Simply because, Village never lets you stay too long in the same place, you'll constantly experience new places, enemies, bosses and plots for the story. There are [spoiler]4 lords[/spoiler] before the main enemy in this game, which you see very early, and they have totally different and appropriate places for their personalities. Basically, you'll meet someone new, begin to understand your enemy and its territory while investigating the main plot, along with nicely designed action sequences. And when you finish that part, totally different experience awaits. Sometimes it will be scary, sometimes disgusting, sometimes thrilling, sometimes fun and intriguing, but it will never be the same.

[h3] What About Cons? [/h3] 
This game doesn't have any major flaws as I see it. It doesn't have constant horror scenes and you probably won't run out of ammo in standard difficulty, but these are personal preferences. I agree that this game could be longer, at least 10-12 hours would really be great. But Village already does a great job and offers variety in weapons, places, bosses, enemies and concludes story in a nice way. There are no meaningless time-spending sections nor rushed plots, so the length is just how it should be.

Resident Evil Village is the 8th entry in the survival-horror series Resident Evil. After the 6th game, which received backlash for not following the series’ survival-horror roots, Capcom decided to make a game with a smaller scope, and one that was more horror focused. That game was Resident Evil 7. It was widely praised, and Capcom had the unenviable task of following it up. Resident Evil Village was their followup.
I 100% recommend playing Resident Evil 7 before Village. While there is a recap of the story of 7 in Village, you should play it yourself to know the story. It is an incredible game. But this review is about Village, not 7. Is it as good as 7? Is it better perhaps? I guess you’ll have to read this long ass essay.
Now, if you don’t like reading (like 80% of everyone I’ve met), you can skip to the last paragraph. If you do like reading, here’s my review.

Story
Village takes place a couple of years after 7. You still play as Ethan Winters. Mia, Ethan’s wife, is reading a book to Rose, their newborn daughter. It is a local book, as they’ve moved somewhere in Europe. It creeps Ethan out, but evidently not Rose, as she is put to sleep. Just after Ethan puts Rose to sleep, Mia is shot and killed by… Chris Redfield? Without explaining, they capture Rose and a bewildered Ethan. 
Ethan wakes up outside a crashed Umbrella van, in a snowy forest in the middle of nowhere. He ventures to a village where all of the residents are evil. There are some who are not, but they’re extremely paranoid. He soon finds out that an epidemic has come over this village, where the people turn into beasts called Lycans. They worship a being known as Mother Miranda as some sort of way to keep them sane. Ultimately, everything goes to shit and Ethan is captured once more, this time by the Lycans. He is then brought in front of Mother Miranda, where four of, seemingly, her children argue on how to kill him. Ethan is chased by Lycans throughout a dungeon after this argument, and he ends up in one of the children’s (Lady Dimitrescu, who you’ve probably already heard of before) castle. Your goal (for now) is to escape Castle Dimitrescu and find Rose.
This story has a lot more moving parts than the last story. It’s much more complicated. It also has way more cutscenes than the last game did. It also characterizes Ethan more, where in the last game, he was pretty much just a silent protagonist who would echo your thoughts occasionally, in this game, a crazy development occurred and he actually has a personality. 

Gameplay
Resident Evil has always been a survival-horror series. Village is no different. You explore the areas, sliming opps, solving puzzles, and being scared, now in the 1st person, just like the last game. Village leans a tad more into the action side of the series than 7 did; it’s not full-blown RE4 levels, but it’s more than 7. The general pace of the game is faster, and I think this is actually worse for the horror experience. You can get away quicker, and the gunplay feels less good as a result. Also, the physics are dumbed down. You can’t shoot off individual body parts like you could in 7. There are also no storage boxes, which I find odd. My last complaint is that cutscenes are often intrusive, like some of them take forever. I get it’s a horror game and it’s about atmosphere, but sometimes I just want to play the game, you know?
That seemed negative, but Village gets a lot of things right. For starters, there is a shop system. In 7, there were some cages you could open. Here, a fat man named the Duke sells you things, such as resources, upgrades, and foods, and he can buy various treasures you can collect from enemies. I know this system existed in prior games, but this is my first experience with it, and it’s a welcome addition. Also, the greater focus on action leads to some pretty sick setpieces, one of which you’ll see at the very start of the game. Probably the game’s biggest strength is its exploration. In 7, it would gate certain areas off from you. In Village, while it occasionally does that, you will always be able to return to the areas later. There are a lot more secrets and hidden areas in this one, which is just flat-out cool. They also reworked the inventory system slightly so that key items don’t take up space in your normal inventory. You also have to slide resources around in order to make space. Some people don’t like this, but I think it’s pretty alright.

I’m not sure if I could call either game’s general gameplay loop better than the other. They are separate experiences meant to cater to different parts of their audiences. What I will say, at the very least, is that the gameplay loops are similar enough so that if you liked 7’s, you will like Village’s.

Presentation
Village is set in a rural, mountainous area somewhere in Europe, speculated to be Romania, but there’s no way of knowing. Village is beautiful. This is what they’re talking about when they say a “9th-gen game”. All around it’s very pretty. It’s also good at establishing an atmosphere, a lot like its predecessor. It’s odd, because the settings are polar opposites, but its atmosphere feels similar. I hear that Village tries to be 4, which takes place in a similar setting and has a similar atmosphere, so good on you, Capcom.
I wanted to mention this somewhere, but I didn’t know where, so here it is. In the last game, they never actually showed Ethan’s face, which sort of became a joke in the community, and in this game, they double down on it. There are a handful of renders of him, but his face is always covered or shadowed. I thought that was really funny. This series certainly is good at inside jokes.
The sound effects are good, but not as good as the previous game. In 7 they just seemed to stand out more. Here, they’re very solid though, and add to the ambience. There’s very little music, and when there is music, it fits. As for the voice acting, besides for one character, I would say it’s very, VERY good. 
There’s even a photo mode so you can take cool screenshots of this game and make them like your wallpaper or something.

Content
According to Howlongtobeat.com, RE Village is roughly 10 hours long, which is a good length. There is much more to explore in this one than in 7 though. The new focus on exploration leads to it being much easier and much more fun to dig through and 100%. There are a lot more optional treasures and secrets in the village. It actually does a really good job at keeping those hours distinct, too. Another thing this game (and this series) does well is the pacing. In a 10 hour game, it isn’t too hard to have good pacing, but this one keeps you hooked throughout the whole thing. I was always curious to see what would come next.
In the way of story DLC, there’s only 1, being the Winters’ expansion. It’s about 3 hours long. I have not played it, and chances are I won’t, because it costs too much to justify its runtime for me. I hear it reuses lots of areas as well, and the only big difference is it being in a 3rd person camera angle.
There are also some side modes, the most well known being Mercenaries. Village’s version of Mercenaries is less replayable than previous iterations of it, but it essentially tasks you with defeating all of the enemies in an area as efficiently as possible. You can play as either Ethan or Chris in the base game, and get more characters with DLC.
There are a handful of other DLCs, but I frankly don’t care about them enough to cover them. They aren’t story expansions, so I don’t care. 
This game has a lot of DLC. But it has a lot of base-game content, as well.

Negatives:

Cut scenes will have monsters do shockingly brutal things to the player, then the player walks away with "merely a flesh wound".  After the third or forth fatal injury the shock has been lost.

And if being effectively immortal isn't enough, so many times the protagonist should have failed his mission but is spared because the villains have contrived idiocy.

Ethan has enough plot armor to swallow a nuke.

Village feels like a bait-and-switch, where its layout appears non-linear but is gated to be linear.  Part of the problem is with Village's "theme-park" layout with separate lands, it's like a Mega Man game without being able to choose which level to play next.

Imma be frank, this isn't it. It isn't RE6 bad, but it just doesn't work. They tried to mix RE7 (great game) with RE4 (also great game) but it doesn't work because both are completely different game styles. You can't be a slow paced survival horror game AND an action horror game. So that leaves us with this poorly paced mess of a game.

The short and dirty for this game is that it's really well made, and really boring. Resident evil as a franchise is torn between the classic puzzle solving, exploration, and inventory management survival horror of the ps1 era games and the action horror of post resident evil 4 until RE 7 went back to survival horror. This game tries to pay homage to both eras with middling success. 

On the classic survival horror side: Village has maps that slowly open up and loop back to earlier sections as you obtain more puzzle items and keys. The problem is, with the exception of the main hub area, that the maps are too short and basic due to this game being split up into different sections that all have different vibes that they're going for. You don't have much time to really familiarize yourself with the layout of the level before being pushed into the next gameplay chapter. The puzzles are also very basic.

On the action horror side: Village pays a lot of homage to RE 4. You have upgradable weapons, an eccentric merchant, and a moment early in the game that is very reminiscent of the opening segment of RE 4. The problem is the combat isn't very good. Guns have minimal impact and village doesn't have the arcade-y movement and melee options from RE 4. You just shoot enemies until they're dead.

The game does have good parts, the hub area you revisit between main segments is the highlight of the game as it slowly opens up each time you revisit it. I also won't go into spoilers, but there is a segment in this game that probably the scariest the franchise has ever been. unfortunately, this part is a slog on replays.

Buy on a deep sale, or better yet replay RE 4 or its remake.
